page.title: 01Dinas Powys/Wenvoe Area
page.content: The surveyed area lies to the south-west of {CARDIFF}being situated midway between the city and the coastal town of {BARRY}. The region is best described as an undulating lowland with no place exceeding 400 feet (130 metres) in height above sea level. Indeed, much of the district is below 300 feet (95 metres) and almost entirely dominated by rural countryside. Only in the extreme south-east does the expanding village of Dinas Powys encroach into this area. Geologically the region can be divided into two distinctive rock types: Limestone dating back some 350 million years (Carboniferous) dominates the higher elevations, whilst Triassic marls (180 million years) form much of the lower aspects.
